document.docAuthor: Barbosa, Julianna Freires, Ribeiro, José Ricardo Inacio & Nessimian, Jorge Luiz
document.masterDocTitle: A synopsis of Martarega White, 1879 (Insecta: Heteroptera: Notonectidae) occurring in the Brazilian Amazonia, with descriptions of three new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A synopsis of Martarega White, 1879 (Insecta: Heteroptera: Notonectidae) occurring in the Brazilian Amazonia, with descriptions of three new species

bibRefCitation.author: Truxal FS
bibRefCitation.refString: Truxal FS. 1949. A study of the genus Martarega (Hemiptera: Notonectidae). Kans Entomol Soc. 22 (1): 1 - 36.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Based on current records,
M. gonostyla
has a roughly northern to central-western South American distribution, being the southernmost record of this species found in Mato Grosso State (Figure 14A). This species and
M. williamsi
are very similar in hemelytral appearance, both having stripes along the costal region of hemelytra and small groups of short bristles distributed throughout mesotrochanter. Specimens of
M. gonostyla
have an enlarged and dark single stripe extending onto the costal margin of hemelytra ( Figure 8A,B ), whereas in
M. williamsi
the hemelytra bear two stripes ( Figure 9A ). Another useful character for separation lies in the outer lateral margin of male mesotrochanters, which on
M. gonostyla
bears three or more small groups of short bristles ( Figure 8C ).

Martarega gonostyla
macropterous forms present brown hemelytra with hyaline stripes, resembling those stripe shapes of macropterous form of
M. uruguayensis
. Its males may be readily differentiated from other male members of
M. gonostyla
by the presence of only one group of short bristles on the ventral surface of their mesotrochanters ( Figure 10D ). Rather than possessing an emargination at the base of the hind femora as seen in
M. uruguayensis
, female specimens of
M. gonostyla
bear instead hind femora with continuous margins.
